subdefinitions.definition: Able to have something pass through or along it.
examples: Come in – the door's open .
The ice has cleared and the channel is open again.

subdefinitions.definition: Not covered , sealed , etc.; having an opening or aperture showing what is inside .
examples: The jewellery box was lying open .
Don't just stand there with your mouth open !
Along the street ran an open sewer.

subdefinitions.definition: Not physically drawn together , folded or contracted .
examples: She greeted them with open arms.
The book was open at page 23.
an open hand; an open flower; an open (loosely woven) fabric

subdefinitions.definition: Of a space , free of objects and obstructions .
examples: It was a large, open room.
Most of the site was occupied by huts, but there was an open area in the centre.
Soon we left the forest behind and we were out in open country.

subdefinitions.definition: Resulting from an incision , puncture or any other process by which the skin no longer protects an internal part of the body.
examples: an open fracture

subdefinitions.definition: Unlocked or unlatched but not physically open.
In a position allowing fluid to flow.
subdefinitions.label_groups: engineering , gas and liquid flow , of valve or damper

subdefinitions.definition: Composed of a single slice of bread with a topping .
examples: open sandwich
subdefinitions.label_groups: of a sandwich, etc. , usually not comparable

subdefinitions.definition: Not of a quality to prevent communication, as by closing waterways, blocking roads, etc.; hence, not frosty or inclement; mild; used of the weather or the climate.
examples: an open winter

definitions.definition: Able to be used or interacted with in some way.

subdefinitions.definition: Available for use or operation.
examples: Your bank account is now open .
Phone lines open at 10 pm.
This is the only option open to us.

subdefinitions.definition: Actively conducting or prepared to conduct business .
examples: Banks are not open on bank holidays.
Several new shops have opened in Market Street.

subdefinitions.definition: Allowing entrance to visitors or the public .
examples: I hereby declare this fete open .
The school has an open day on Saturday.

subdefinitions.definition: Receptive .
examples: I am open to new ideas.

subdefinitions.definition: Susceptible or vulnerable (to the stated means).
examples: open to question; open to attack; open to criticism

subdefinitions.definition: In current use; connected to as a resource.
examples: I couldn't save my changes because another user had the same file open .
subdefinitions.label_groups: computing , not comparable , of a file, document, etc.

subdefinitions.definition: Running .
examples: You're getting short of memory because you have too many apps open .
labels: especially one with a screen-based interface
subdefinitions.label_groups: computing , of a program or application, especially one with a screen-based interface

subdefinitions.definition: Not concealed ; overt .
examples: It is a blatant example of open criminality.

subdefinitions.definition: Of a person, not concealing their feelings , opinions , etc.; candid , ingenuous .
examples: Nowadays people are more open about their sexuality.

subdefinitions.definition: Public .
examples: He published an open letter to the governor on a full page of The New York Times .
The New York Times

subdefinitions.definition: Written or sent with the intention that it may made public or referred to at any trial , rather than by way of confidential private negotiation for a settlement .
examples: You will observe that this is an open letter and we reserve the right to mention it to the judge should the matter come to trial.

subdefinitions.definition: With open access , of open science , or both.
examples: We hope that all aspects of the project will be open rather than paywalled.

subdefinitions.definition: Made public , usable with a free licence and without proprietary components.
Of a tournament or competition , allowing anyone to enter, especially or originally irrespective of professional or amateur status.
Characterised by free-flowing play.
examples: Compared to their last match, which was a dour and defensive affair, this was a very open game.

subdefinitions.definition: Not settled ; not decided or determined ; not withdrawn from consideration .
examples: an open question
to keep an offer or opportunity open

subdefinitions.definition: Not fulfilled or resolved ; incomplete .
examples: I've got open orders for as many containers of red durum as you can get me.

subdefinitions.definition: Not having one end joined to the other; not forming a closed loop .
examples: an open curve, an open circuit

subdefinitions.definition: In a position such that a circuit is not completed, preventing electricity from flowing.
labels: of a switch or circuit breaker
subdefinitions.label_groups: electricity , of a switch or circuit breaker

subdefinitions.definition: Having different first and last vertices.
Ending in a vowel ; not having a coda .

definitions.definition: Which is part of a predefined collection of subsets of X {\displaystyle X} , that defines a topological space on X {\displaystyle X} .
Of a note , played without pressing the string against the fingerboard .
Of a note , played without closing any finger-hole , key or valve .
Uttered with a relatively wide opening of the articulating organs; said of vowels .
Uttered, as a consonant , with the oral passage simply narrowed without closure.
Source code of a computer program that is not within the text of a macro being generated. (Can we add an example for this sense?)
Having component words separated by spaces, as opposed to being joined together or hyphenated; for example, time slot as opposed to timeslot or time-slot .
Of a club , bat or other hitting implement, angled upwards and/or  (for a right-hander ) clockwise of straight.

main_definition: ( usually not comparable ) Physically unobstructed , uncovered , etc.
secondary_definitions: Able to be used or interacted with in some way.
( mathematics , logic , of a formula ) Having a free variable .
( mathematics , topology , of a set ) Which is part of a predefined collection of subsets of X {\displaystyle X} , that defines a topological space on X {\displaystyle X} .
( music , stringed instruments ) Of a note , played without pressing the string against the fingerboard .
( music ) Of a note , played without closing any finger-hole , key or valve .
( phonetics , sometimes with comparative opener ) Uttered with a relatively wide opening of the articulating organs; said of vowels .
( phonetics ) Uttered, as a consonant , with the oral passage simply narrowed without closure.
( computing , used before "code" ) Source code of a computer program that is not within the text of a macro being generated. (Can we add an example for this sense?)
( of a multi-word compound ) Having component words separated by spaces, as opposed to being joined together or hyphenated; for example, time slot as opposed to timeslot or time-slot .
( especially sports ) Of a club , bat or other hitting implement, angled upwards and/or  (for a right-hander ) clockwise of straight.
